title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don’t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: “I fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER”. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let’s examine the reasons: (1) ain’t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‘you’ exist is because your dad’s sperm fertilized your mom’s egg. Somewhere along the way, ‘you’ came into existence. However, the answer to the question “Why did you fall off your bike?” requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously just do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let’s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let’s begin at the moment in which you obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon experiencing reality for the first time, you are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, develop an awareness of your existence (‘consciousness’), achieve control of your thoughts (‘agency’ or ‘creativity’), and eventually learn from your environment (‘intelligence’, ‘cognition’, or as I like to say, ‘an ability to connect the dots’). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‘information’) interpreted as truth (‘knowledge’) and the connections are a model that describes the functional i/o relationships between bits (‘understanding’). It is as if reality is a Turing-Complete system and our brains are the Turing Machine (lol… not an original analogy). Putting this all together, we exist in reality as a conscious, intelligent agent perceiving a series of moments (‘experience’) which we call life. The one thing missing in this analogy is our ‘imagination’ -- the power to “see the unseen”. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is actually inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now … but will definitely discuss it in a future post.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about the past is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration, and trust their observations and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Also, your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- “take nobody’s word for it”. 

An historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it’s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus on its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth … though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying “wisdom of the crowd”. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying “fatality of the mob”. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise, not truth-seeking\*\*\*. There is another common phrase, “history is written by the winners”, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser’s side. This is not all the publisher’s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but this missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias. 

Evidence is a discovery -- a gain of information which completes our understanding and builds our intuition. It is still up to humans to induce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Evidence can indicate the likelihood of a particular events’ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation builds context. It entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase “drawing a conclusion”. Every piece of evidence or account of history has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and imaginative renderings do not prove dinosaurs’ existence. It simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later 'discovers' them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil. 

Evidence is an empirical starting point. We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially history which we did not personally observe (and even when we do observe things … our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, feelings, emotions, and motivation) which we may not be aware of in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). To find the truth, you must first become aware of bias in order to account for its influence during an experience. Bias recognition provides context. With context, you gain perspective and can more accurately determine whether a piece of evidence is circumstantial. At the same time, we will always have missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate account of history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that the world was deterministic because everything can be explained. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don’t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant’s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series which breaks down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that you do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are *First Principles* -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> “**What I cannot create, I do not understand**”
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‘the seen’ in terms of ‘the unseen’. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom’s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root.

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Explanations have degrees of completeness. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and leaves nothing to chance. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‘justified true belief’ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as true. One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation describes a fundamental truth (a law of nature) because there is always a chance that we discover new knowledge debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). The goal of knowledge is to find more knowledge.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retroactively imply causation and also fuel predictions -→ which builds knowledge -→ which inspires imagination -→ which creates explanations. These ‘creations’ brings a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‘you’). Knowledge is not scarce. It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It just exists. It is the purest form of objectivity. Frankly, it does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one major exception. The only natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability about the probability distribution of electrons in spacetime. This gets more interesting when you consider spacetime as a series of sequential instances of reality with quantum randomness at the root. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing information gaps. Here are two ways to reduce information gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- using observations to find correlations between hypothesized independent data and the resulting dependent data.

2\.) explanatory methods -- using imagination to create logical arguments describing cause and effect relationships.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem. Empirical methods are useful to identify information gaps. Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you are getting closer to a casual relationship (though there still may be confounding variables or unaccounted factors which are the root cause). However, correlation is not causation …. so … how do you know if your independent factors are truly independent? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Only explanations can generate new knowledge from information not apparent in the observations. An explanation can implicate unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power\*\*\*\*\*\*. At the same time, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information … so get used to it!

If we assume that reality is deterministic, then do we have free will? Can there be a meaning to life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? Can meaning be defined? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding, but rather consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is also true.

\*\*\*\*\*We may get to this at some point.

\*\*\*\*\*\*Explanatory power is the degree to which a factor causes an effect.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power\*\*\*\*\*\*. At the same time, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information … so get used to it!

If we assume that reality is deterministic, then do we have free will? Can there be a meaning to life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? Can meaning be defined? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding, but rather consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is also true.

\*\*\*\*\*We may get to this at some point.

\*\*\*\*\*\*Explanatory power is the degree to which a factor causes an effect.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

☁️AI Appreciation Thread☁️

Adding #AI to my kit helped me develop an appreciation for the craft in ways that only firsthand experience can give you.

At first blush you might think it's powerful and almost unfair in what it can output so quickly, but 𝗧𝗛𝗔𝗧 is an illusion. 
  
  
 

As an artist, I initially fell for that trap and watched AI cautiously; as people output and sold AI work left and right, art that took me weeks to do, hardly moved at all.

What about 𝕄𝔼?

This dynamic can tap into the worst parts of our humanity... 
  
  
 I try to remind myself constantly that "comparison is the thief of joy".

And while I don't want to get extra meta, I will say that the minute I reframed my thinking from

𝓅𝑜𝓅𝓊𝓁𝒶𝓇𝒾𝓉𝓎

to

🅰🆁🆃 
 was the moment I was able to accept something I had unfairly loathed...

I was also better positioned to see this art with fresh new eyes, and more able to start discerning mastery from apprentice.

I was also better positioned to see this art with fresh new eyes, and more able to understand the craftsmanship; more able to discern mastery from apprentice.

And this was the gift of discovery that I was awarded for daring to open my mind.
